title: German submarine U-307
text:
German submarine "U-307" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 5 November 1941, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 18 November 1942.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-307" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Garbe%2C%20Lahmeyer%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Garbe, Lahmeyer & Co.</a> RP 137/c <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-307" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
Despite carrying out 13 war patrols between July 1943 and April 1945, "U-307" sank only two vessels; the 7,176 GRT American <a href="Liberty%20ship">Liberty ship</a> on 30 April 1944, fifty miles south of <a href="Bear%20Island%20%28Norway%29">Bear Island</a>, and the 50 GRT <a href="Norwegian%20Army">Norwegian Army</a> motor boat "Lennox" in <a href="Van%20Mijenfjorden">Van Mijenfjorden</a>, <a href="Spitsbergen">Spitsbergen</a>, on 18 August 1944.
In September 1944, together with the supply ship "<a href="Carl%20J.%20Busch">Carl J. Busch</a>", "U-307" transported the men of <a href="Operation%20Haudegen">Operation Haudegen</a>, a German military meteorological mission, to <a href="Svalbard">Svalbard</a>.

Fate.
"U-307" was sunk on 29 April 1945 in the <a href="Barents%20Sea">Barents Sea</a> near <a href="Murmansk">Murmansk</a>, Russia, in position by depth charges from the British <a href="Loch%20class%20frigate">Loch class frigate</a> . There were 37 dead and 14 survivors.
